title: Iraq imposes curfew on Baghdad as protest death toll mounts
text:
At least 13 people have been killed since Tuesday - REUTERS

Iraq’s government imposed a curfew on Baghdad and largely shut off the internet on Thursday as it struggles to reimpose order after three days of bloody protests that have left 19 people dead.

At least 18 demonstrators and one policeman have been killed since protests erupted on Tuesday against government corruption, poor public services, and high levels of unemployment. Nearly 800 people have been injured.

Several explosions were heard early Thursday in the Green Zone, the central Baghdad district that houses foreign embassies and government buildings, but no casualties were reported.

The US-led military coalition fighting against the Islamic State (Isil) called the violence “deeply concerning” and “urged all sides to reduce tensions”.

Adel Abdel Mahdi, Iraq’s prime minister, ordered an indefinite curfew in Baghdad from 5am Thursday. “All vehicles and individuals are totally forbidden to move in Baghdad,” the order stated.

Demonstrators gesture at a protest over unemployment, corruption and poor public services, in Baghdad Credit: REUTERS/Thaier al-Sudani More

Travellers to and from Baghdad airport, ambulances, government employees in hospitals, electricity, and water departments, and religious pilgrims are exempt from the curfew, the statement said.

Ignoring the curfew order, protesters once took to the streets and clashed with security forces on Thursday. Iraqi troops fired live rounds into the air to try to disperse demonstrators from Baghdad’s Tahrir Square.

Amid the chaos, Hussein Adel Madani, a cartoonist, was shot dead along with his wife, Sara, by masked gunmen who stormed their house in Basra early on Thursday, officials said. Their two-year-old daughter, Zahra, was not harmed.

The couple had taken part in protests but it was not clear if their deaths were directly linked to the unrest. A number of activists have been assassinated in Basra this year.

The Iraqi government has virtually cut off the internet in an effort to stop protesters spreading news and images of the demonstrations on social media.

Tests by NetBlocks, an internet freedom group, found that around 75 per cent of the country was without internet. Applications and messaging services like WhatsApp, Facebook, and Twitter have all been blocked.

Two explosions were reported in the Green Zone around dawn on Thursday. It was unclear what the cause but the area was hit by two rockets last week.

Hours earlier security forces sealed the Green Zone “until further notice” out of concerns that protesters may try to storm the area. It was only re-opened to the public in June for the first time since the 2003 US invasion of Iraq.

The protests represent a severe challenge to Mr Abdel Mahdi, who took office only a year ago. In an effort to stem the protests he announced new measures to help graduates find work and promised to force foreign companies to hire more local workers.

An Iraqi protestor gestures in front of security forces during a demonstration against state corruption, failing public services and unemployment Credit: HUSSEIN FALEH/AFP via Getty Images More
